text: Have there been discussions about what it mean to be a `Real` and/or what defines its interface? I feel like I keep running into rough edges because the concept is relatively ill-defined and prone to competing interpretations. For example if a type implement all arithmetic operations and comparisons (e.g. `Quantity`s from `Unitful` that does not subtype `Real`) shouldn't they be fully compatible? And if they are shouldn't they subtype the abstract `Real` type even so they are no strictly speaking reals (or even numbers)?

text:
`Real` possibly shouldn't exist in the type hierarchy. (`AbstractFloat` even more so.)
I guess the requirement for `Real` over other numbers is that they are Orderable. Complex numbers are not, and you can wrap a `Quanity` around a complex number,and if you do `<=` will stop working.

Possibly commutative multiplication us also required? Real (and Complex) have that but quaternions don't.

text: I agree with <@U6A936746> that our lives would be much easier if some of these abstract types were gone and people started go rely more on behavior with traits like < instead of explicit dispatch. I guess that would lead to another level of integration across different packages using some kind of scalar type.
